items.title: Hello and Welcome!
items.description: We set up this program to help you get started with contributing to our projects. If you follow the steps in this program, you'll be able to make your first contribution in no time! Some of you have worked in groups on large projects before, while others are completely new to this way of working and these systems. If you don't understand something in these tasks, you might want to search unfamiliar terms online, ask a chatbot, or ask one of the su-permen so we can give you help with the whole context. If a task seems trivial to you, that's great! Feel free to skip it and move on to the next step. The goal is to get you comfortable and confident in contributing to our projects no matter what level you start from.
items.task: I have read the text above and am ready to get started!

items.title: Ask Us Questions!
items.description: Su-permen are here to help you. If you get stuck, or if anything is unclear, ask us right away! Even su-permen get stuck *all the time* on things we feel we should know. Our projects are really weird and much of the knowledge is not written down anywhere. As a general rule, if you've spent more than 15 minutes trying to figure something out it's time to ask for help, but asking earlier is always better.
items.task: I promise to ask questions when in doubt.

items.title: Install Git
items.description: Git is a version control system that we use to manage our codebase for all our projects. Read and follow [this guide to install and configure Git for our projects](https://fsek.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installing_systems/installation_web/installation.html#setting-up-git). **Don't do the Docker part yet!**

items.title: Set Your Display Name On GitHub
items.description: We need to know who you are! Add your real name to your GitHub profile. You can do that [here](https://github.com/settings/profile), change your display name or add it to your bio.
items.task: There is some way to identify my real identity on my GitHub profile.

items.title: Pick Your Project
items.description:
You should focus on getting good at working on one of our projects at a time. Pick one of the app, frontend for the web or backend to focus on. Don't worry if you feel like it's a tough choice, you can always switch later on!

- **Frontend**: Work here can take many forms, but generally you will be building or editing webpages with some logic or forms on them. We need more people here, so if you're unsure, this is a good choice! You don't need to be great at design or have a passion for graphical design to work on the frontend.
- **Backend**: Work here is backend-focused. If you like working with databases and APIs, this is the choice for you! The backend is a little more focused on logic and covering edge cases than the frontend.
- **App**: Like the web, work here is frontend-focused. Installation might be a bit tricky (we'll help you), but if you feel drawn to mobile development, this is the way to go!

Can't decide? Ask a su-perman for more information about the different projects!
items.task: I have picked one of them to focus on and learn first.

items.title: Install the Repository
items.description:
Depending on what project you picked, this will differ:

- **Frontend**: Follow the instructions in the [WWW-Web README](https://github.com/fsek/WWW-Web).
- **Backend**: Follow the instructions in the [WebWebWeb README](https://github.com/fsek/WebWebWeb).
- **App**: Follow the instructions in the [app README](https://github.com/fsek/App2).

Make sure to reach out to a su-perman if you run into any issues!
items.task: I have successfully finished following the README and the project launches properly (you probably want to ask a su-perman to check this).

items.title: Choose Your First Issue
items.description: Now that you have your environment set up and the project running, it's time to make your first contribution! Pick a small issue from the issue tracker of your project (one tagged as 'Good First Issue'), or ask a su-perman for a suggestion. It's important that you assign the issue to yourself so that others know you're working on it. Ask a su-perman if you're unsure how to do this.
items.task: I have picked an issue _**and assigned it to myself**_.

items.title: Work on Your Issue
items.description: Now that you've picked an issue, it's time to start working on it!
items.task: I have finished working on my issue and tested my changes locally.

items.title: Create a Pull Request
items.description: Once you've completed your changes and tested them locally, it's time to create a pull request (PR) to propose your changes to the main codebase. Push your changes to a new branch in the repository and open a PR against the main branch. Write a description of what you've done and write "resolves #issue_number" in the PR description to automatically close the issue when the PR is merged. Ask a su-perman if you need help with this step.
items.task: I have created a pull request for my changes. It includes a description of what I've done and links to the issue it resolves.

items.title: Request a Code Review
items.description: The su-permen need to know that your PR is ready for review. Request a review from multiple su-permen using the sidebar to the right. They will look over your code, provide feedback, and suggest any necessary changes. Don't be discouraged if they request changes: it's all part of the learning process! If you get to this step during a meeting, tell the su-permen present that your PR is ready for review and they will review it ASAP.
items.task: I have requested a code review from more than one su-perman.

items.title: Finish Your Pull Request And Merge
items.description: After your PR has been reviewed and approved by the su-permen, it's time to merge it into the main codebase. Make sure to address any feedback provided during the review process before merging. Once everything is in order, you can merge your PR. Congratulations on completing your first contribution!
items.task: My pull request has been approved and merged into the main branch.

completionMessage: Great job on completing the onboarding program! You're now ready to start contributing to our projects. (We recommend you pick one tagged as a 'Good First Issue' or 'Good Second Issue'.) Remember, the su-permen are always here to help you along the way. Welcome aboard! üï∑Ô∏è
